awd_titl_txt: Conference: Fire Resilience of Physical Civil Infrastructure; Reston, Virginia; Fall 2024
awd_abstract_narration:
Fires in the United States result in annual costs in the billions of dollars, including direct property losses, indirect losses from business interruptions, and losses from injuries and deaths. The United States has witnessed the devastating impacts of wildfires on communities. Wildfire activity (the number of fire days, intensity, and impacts) has increased rapidly in recent decades, yet it is projected to increase even further due to climate change and anthropogenic activities, especially in wildland-urban interface (WUI) areas where people live. Structure fires have provided the engineering community with valuable insights into the behavior and impact of fires and fire safety design of civil infrastructure. Recently, experts in resilient fire design of civil infrastructure have applied their knowledge of fire safety design to understand and mitigate wildfire impacts to communities within the WUI. This award will support an engineering workshop to gather key experts from academe, industry, government agencies, and national laboratories within the United States in the field of resilient fire design of civil infrastructure to (1) share perspectives on available resources and facilities for experimental fire testing; (2) identify research needs, gaps, and challenges facing fire resilience of civil infrastructure, considering the emergence of new structural materials, increased wildfire demands due to climate change, and other emerging stressors; and (3) formulate a basic research and education agenda for fire resilience of physical civil infrastructure. 

The workshop will be held for two days in Fall 2024 at the American Society of Civil Engineers headquarters in Reston, Virginia. The workshop will identify fundamental research needs in achieving fire resilience of civil infrastructure for the following topics: (1) impacts of structural (or internal) fires on buildings and structures; (2) impacts of WUI (or external) fires on buildings and structures, including residential construction; (3) impacts of fires on transportation structures (excluding pavements); (4) impacts of fires on utilities; and (5) impacts of fires on geotechnical failures. For these topics, the workshop discussions will be structured to identify needs in four areas: in-field investigations, experimental research, numerical/analytical research, and educational approaches. The ideas presented by the speakers and generated from the discussion sessions will be summarized in a final report and published through the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) Data Depot (https://www.DesignSafe-ci.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fire causes significant physical, social, and financial damage to the infrastructure throughout the U.S. each year. The increasing intensity and frequency of wildfires threaten infrastructure within the wildland urban interface (WUI) communities throughout the U.S., where one-third of the contiguous U.S. population lives. The recent mega-fires have caused significant damage to not only single-family homes within WUI communities, but also to critical infrastructure and commercial entities such as schools and health care facilities, in addition to utilities such as water and power infrastructure. Meanwhile, the development of performance-based design codes for other natural hazards (e.g., earthquake, wind) has highlighted the lack of probabilistic data for building construction materials and the need for uncertainty quantification of fire demands to enable the implementation of performance-based fire methodologies for building structures. With the continual emergence of new construction materials (e.g. mass timber), the field of structural fire engineering faces many gaps in knowledge that must be addressed through research to further develop fire-resilient infrastructure and fire-adaptive communities. To identify and prioritize these gaps in knowledge, the “Fire Resilience of Physical Civil Infrastructure” conference was hosted on November 12 – 13, 2024, bringing together key thought leaders and agencies within the U.S. in the field of resilient fire design of civil infrastructure.

The objectives of the “Fire Resilience of Physical Civil Infrastructure” conference were to: (1) share perspectives on available resources and facilities for experimental testing from various agencies and institutions, (2) identify needs, gaps, and challenges facing fire resilience of physical civil infrastructure considering the emergence of new structural materials, increased wildfire demands, and other emerging stressors; and (3) formulate recommendations for basic research initiatives. These objectives were accomplished across both impacts of (A) structural (or internal) fires on buildings and structures, including transportation structures, and (B) WUI (or external) fires on buildings and structures, utilities, and geotechnical failures. The ideas generated throughout the conference were characterized by numerical simulations, experimental testing, in-field investigations, and workforce development. Conference attendees, particularly those from academia, submitted abstracts summarizing state-of-the-art knowledge and research gaps. A summary of the abstracts as well as all the submitted abstracts were published on DesignSafe-CI and distributed to the attendees prior to the conference.

A final report summarizing all of the discussions was also published on DesignSafe. The discussions were organized into Research Needs, Research Priorities, Research Infrastructure Needs, and Workforce Development. The conference identified critical research needs to advance fire resilience across materials, components, and systems, and for short-term, mid-term, and long-term time frames. Discussions highlighted the importance of coordinated and integrated efforts across field investigations, experimental testing, and numerical simulations to capture the complex behavior of infrastructure under both structural (internal) and WUI (external) fires. These efforts will include coordinated post-fire data collection, generation of reliable data from experimental tests, and model validation methodologies. Advancing fire resilience requires a unified national effort to expand research infrastructure, modernize testing methodologies, establish new approaches to characterize and quantify the fire hazard and its impacts, and develop a skilled, interdisciplinary workforce. Strategic investments in these priorities will enable the creation of fire-resilient infrastructure and fire-adaptive communities.
